optcom.parameters.fiber package¶

Submodules¶

optcom.parameters.fiber.absorption_section module¶

class optcom.parameters.fiber.absorption_section.AbsorptionSection(dopant='yb', medium='sio2', T=293.1, sigma_e=None)¶

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

Parameters

  • dopant -- The doping medium.

  • medium -- The fiber medium.

  • T -- The absolute temperature. \([K]\)

  • sigma_e -- A callable which return the emission cross section. \([nm^2]\) If a callable, the parameters must be the angular frequencies. \([ps^{-1}]\) If none is provided, use fitting formulas.

static calc_sigma(omega, coefficients, lambda_range=None)¶

Calculate the absorption cross section. Calculate with the fitting formula from ref. 1 .

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • coefficients -- The coefficients for the fitting formula. \([\text{factor}, l_c, l_w, n]\)

  • lambda_range -- The range of wavelength in which the fitting formula is valid. (lower_bound, upper_bound)

Returns

Value of the absorption cross section. \([nm^2]\)

Return type

float or numpy.ndarray of float

Notes

Considering:

\[f(\lambda, \lambda_c, \lambda_w, n) = \exp\Big[-\Big\lvert \frac{\lambda-\lambda_c}{\lambda_w}\Big\rvert^n \Big]\]

With \(\lambda\), \(\lambda_c\) and \(\lambda_w\) in \([nm]\)

For Ytterbium:

\[\sigma^{Yb}(\lambda) = 0.09f(\lambda,913,8,2) + 0.13 f(\lambda,950,40,4) + 0.2 f(\lambda, 968, 40, 2.4) + 1.08 f(\lambda, 975.8,3,1.5)\]

For Erbium:

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} \sigma^{Er}(\lambda) &= 0.221 f(\lambda, 1493, 16.5, 2.2) + 0.342 f(\lambda, 1534, 4.5, 1.4)\\ &\quad + 0.158f(\lambda, 1534, 30,4) + 0.037 f(\lambda, 1534, 85, 4) + 0.132 f(\lambda, 1541, 8,0.8) \end{split}\end{split}\]

References

1

Valley, G.C., 2001. Modeling cladding-pumped Er/Yb fiber amplifiers. Optical Fiber Technology, 7(1), pp.21-44.

optcom.parameters.fiber.asymmetry_coeff module¶

class optcom.parameters.fiber.asymmetry_coeff.AsymmetryCoeff(beta_1, beta_2)¶

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

Parameters

  • beta_1 -- The zeroth order Taylor series dispersion coefficient of first waveguide. \([km^{-1}]\) If callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • beta_2 -- The zeroth order Taylor series dispersion coefficient of second waveguide. \([km^{-1}]\) If callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

static calc_delta(beta_1, beta_2)¶

Calculate the measure of asymmetry for the parameters given for two waveguides. 2

Parameters

  • beta_1 -- The first term of the propagation constant of the first waveguide. \([km^{-1}]\)

  • beta_2 -- The first term of the propagation constant of the second waveguide. \([km^{-1}]\)

Returns

Value of the asymmetry measure. \([km^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[\delta_{a12} = \frac{1}{2} (\beta_{01} - \beta_{02})\]

References

2

Govind Agrawal, Chapter 2: Fibers Couplers, Applications of Nonlinear Fiber Optics (Second Edition), Academic Press, 2008, Page 57.

optcom.parameters.fiber.coupling_coeff module¶

class optcom.parameters.fiber.coupling_coeff.CouplingCoeff(v_nbr, a, d, ref_index)¶

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

Parameters

  • v_nbr -- The V number. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • a -- The core radius. \([\mu m]\)

  • d -- The center to center spacing between the two cores. \([\mu m]\)

  • ref_index -- The refractive index outside of the two fiber cores. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

static calc_kappa(omega, v_nbr, a, d, ref_index)¶

Calculate the coupling coefficient for the parameters given for two waveguides. (assuming the two waveguides are symmetric) 3

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • v_nbr -- The fiber parameter.

  • a -- The core radius. \([\mu m]\)

  • d -- The center to center spacing between the two cores. \([\mu m]\)

  • ref_index -- The refractive index outside of the two fiber cores.

Returns

Value of the coupling coefficient. \([km^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[\kappa = \frac{\pi V}{2 k_0 n_0 a^2} e^{-(c_0 + c_1 d + c_2 d^2)}\]

This equation is accurate to within 1% for values of the fiber parameter \(1.5\leq V\leq 2.5\) and of the normalized center-to-center spacing \(\bar{d} = d/a\), \(2\leq \bar{d}\leq 4.5\) .

References

3

Govind Agrawal, Chapter 2: Fibers Couplers, Applications of Nonlinear Fiber Optics (Second Edition), Academic Press, 2008, Page 59.

optcom.parameters.fiber.doped_fiber_gain module¶

class optcom.parameters.fiber.doped_fiber_gain.DopedFiberGain(sigma, overlap, N)¶

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

Parameters

  • sigma -- The cross sections. \([nm^2]\) If a callable is provided, the variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • overlap -- The overlap factors. If a callable is provided, the variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • N -- The state density population. \([nm^{-3}]\) If a callable is provided, the variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

property N¶
static calc_doped_fiber_gain(sigma, overlap, N)¶

Calculate the energy saturation.

Parameters

  • sigma -- The cross sections. \([nm^2]\)

  • overlap -- The overlap factors.

  • N -- The state density population. \([nm^{-3}]\)

Returns

Value of the gain. \([km^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[g(\omega) = \Gamma(\omega) \sigma(\omega) N(\omega)\]

optcom.parameters.fiber.effective_area module¶

class optcom.parameters.fiber.effective_area.EffectiveArea(v_nbr, core_radius)¶

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

Effective area, currently only for single mode.

Parameters

  • v_nbr -- The V number. If a callable is provided, the variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • core_radius -- The radius of the core. \([\mu m]\)

static calc_effective_area(v_nbr, core_radius)¶

Calculate the effective area. 4

Parameters

  • v_nbr -- The v_nbr number.

  • core_radius -- The radius of the core. \([\mu m]\)

Returns

Value of the effective area. \([\mu m^2]\)

Notes

\[A_{eff} = \pi w^2 = \pi \big(a(0.616 + 1.66V^{-\frac{2}{3}} + 0.987V^{-6})\big)^2\]

References

4

Govind Agrawal, Chapter 2: Pulse Propagation in Fibers, Nonlinear Fiber Optics (Fifth Edition), Academic Press, 2013, Page 34.

property core_radius¶
property v_nbr¶

optcom.parameters.fiber.emission_section module¶

class optcom.parameters.fiber.emission_section.EmissionSection(dopant='yb', medium='sio2', T=293.1, sigma_a=None)¶

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

Parameters

  • dopant -- The doping medium.

  • medium -- The fiber medium.

  • T -- The absolute temperature. \([K]\)

  • sigma_a -- A callable which return the absorption cross section. \([nm^2]\) If a callable is provided, the parameters must be the angular frequencies. \([ps^{-1}]\) If none is provided, will construct a parameters.fiber. absorption_section.AbsorptionSection object.

static calc_sigma(omega, sigma_a, T, medium, dopant)¶

Calculate the emission cross section. There is no analytical formula for the emission cross section. Calculate first the absorption cross sections with the fitting formula from ref. 5 and then use the McCumber relations to deduce the emission cross sections.

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • medium -- The type of the doped medium.

  • center_omega -- The center angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • N_0 -- The population in ground state. \([nm^{-3}]\)

  • N_1 -- The population in the excited state. \([nm^{-3}]\)

  • T -- The temperature. \([K]\)

Returns

Value of the emission cross section. \([nm^2]\)

References

5

Valley, G.C., 2001. Modeling cladding-pumped Er/Yb fiber amplifiers. Optical Fiber Technology, 7(1), pp.21-44.

optcom.parameters.fiber.energy_saturation module¶

class optcom.parameters.fiber.energy_saturation.EnergySaturation(eff_area, sigma_a, sigma_e, overlap)¶

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

Parameters

  • eff_area -- The effective area. \([\mu m^2]\) If a callable is provided, the variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • sigma_a -- The absorption cross sections. \([nm^2]\) If a callable is provided, the variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • sigma_e -- The emission cross sections. \([nm^2]\) If a callable is provided, the variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • overlap -- The overlap factors. If a callable is provided, the variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

static calc_energy_saturation(omega, eff_area, sigma_a, sigma_e, overlap)¶

Calculate the energy saturation.

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • eff_area -- The effective area. \([\mu m^2]\)

  • sigma_a -- The absorption cross sections. \([nm^2]\)

  • sigma_e -- The emission cross sections. \([nm^2]\)

  • overlap -- The overlap factors.

Returns

Value of the energy saturation. \([J]\)

Notes

\[E_{sat} = \frac{A_{eff}h\omega_0}{2\pi\Gamma \big(\sigma_e(\lambda_0)+\sigma_a(\lambda_0)\big)}\]

optcom.parameters.fiber.nl_coefficient module¶

class optcom.parameters.fiber.nl_coefficient.NLCoefficient(nl_index, eff_area)¶

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

Parameters

  • nl_index -- The non linear index. \([m^2\cdot W^{-1}]\)

  • eff_erea -- The effective area. \([\mu m^2]\)

static calc_nl_coefficient(omega, nl_index, eff_area)¶

Calculate the non linear parameter. 6

Parameters

  • omega -- The center angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • nl_index -- The non linear refractive index. \([m^{2}\cdot W^{-1}]\)

  • eff_area -- The effective mode area. \([\mu m^{2}]\)

Returns

Value of the non linear parameter. \([rad\cdot W^{-1}\cdot km^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[\gamma(\omega_0) = \frac{\omega_0 n_2}{c A_{eff}}\]

References

6

Govind Agrawal, Chapter 2: Pulse Propaga(omega_0)tion in Fibers, Nonlinear Fiber Optics (Fifth Edition), Academic Press, 2013, Page 38.

static calc_nl_length(power, nl_coeff)¶

Calculate the non linear length.

Parameters

  • power -- The power. \([W]\)

  • nl_coeff -- The non linear coefficient. \([rad\cdot W^{-1}\cdot km^{-1}]\)

Returns

The non-linear length \([km]\)

Notes

\[L_{NL} = \frac{1}{\gamma P_0}\]

optcom.parameters.fiber.numerical_aperture module¶

class optcom.parameters.fiber.numerical_aperture.NumericalAperture(n_core, n_clad)¶

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

Parameters

  • n_core -- The refractive index of the core. If a callable is provided, the variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • n_clad -- The refractive index of the cladding. If a callable is provided, the variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

static calc_NA(n_core, n_clad)¶

Calculate the numerical aperture.

Parameters

  • n_core -- The refractive index of the core.

  • n_clad -- The refractive index of the cladding.

Returns

The numerical aperture.

Notes

\[NA = \sqrt{n_{co}^2 - n_{cl}^2}\]
static calc_n_clad(NA, n_core)¶

Calculate the numerical aperture.

Parameters

  • NA -- The numerical aperture.

  • n_core -- The refractive index of the core.

Returns

The refractive index of the cladding.

Notes

\[n_{cl} = \sqrt{n_{co}^2 - NA^2}\]
static calc_n_core(NA, n_clad)¶

Calculate the numerical aperture.

Parameters

  • NA -- The numerical aperture.

  • n_clad -- The refractive index of the cladding.

Returns

The refractive index of the core.

Notes

\[n_{co} = \sqrt{NA^2 + n_{cl}^2}\]
property n_clad¶
property n_core¶

Value of the overlap factor.

\[\Gamma = 1 - e^{-2\frac{A_{doped}}{A_{eff}}}\]

optcom.parameters.fiber.raman_response module¶

class optcom.parameters.fiber.raman_response.RamanResponse(tau_1=0.0122, tau_2=0.032, tau_b=0.096, f_a=0.75, f_b=0.21, f_c=0.04)¶

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

Parameters

  • tau_1 -- The inverse of vibrational frequency of the fiber core molecules. \([ps]\)

  • tau_2 -- The damping time of vibrations. \([ps]\)

  • tau_b -- The spectral width of the Boson peak. \([ps]\)

  • f_a -- The fractional contribution of the isotropic part to the isotropic Raman function.

  • f_b -- The fractional contribution of the anisotropic part to the anisotropic Raman function.

  • f_c -- The fractional contributian of the isotropic part to the anisotropic Raman function.

static calc_h_R(time, tau_1=0.0122, tau_2=0.032, tau_b=0.096, f_a=0.75, f_b=0.21, f_c=0.04)¶

Calculate the Raman response function as the sum of the isotropic \(R_a(t)\) and anisotropic \(R_b(t)\) (Boson peak) Raman response functions. 7

Parameters

  • time -- The time value(s). \([ps]\)

  • tau_1 -- The inverse of vibrational frequency of the fiber core molecules. \([ps]\)

  • tau_2 -- The damping time of vibrations. \([ps]\)

  • tau_b -- The spectral width of the Boson peak. \([ps]\)

  • f_a -- The fractional contribution of the isotropic part to the isotropic Raman function.

  • f_b -- The fractional contribution of the anisotropic part to the anisotropic Raman function.

  • f_c -- The fractional contributian of the isotropic part to the anisotropic Raman function.

Returns

Value of the Raman response function at the time given as parameter. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} h_R(t) &= R_a(t) + R_b(t)\\ &= (f_a h_a(t)) + (f_b h_b(t) + f_c h_a(t))\\ &= (f_a+f_c)h_a(t) + f_b h_b(t) \end{split}\end{split}\]

References

7

Lin, Q. and Agrawal, G.P., 2006. Raman response function for silica fibers. Optics letters, 31(21), pp.3086-3088.

static calc_h_a(time, tau_1=0.0122, tau_2=0.032)¶

Calculate the isotropic part of the Raman response function. 8

Parameters

  • time -- The time value(s). \([ps]\)

  • tau_1 -- The inverse of vibrational frequency of the fiber core molecules. \([ps]\)

  • tau_2 -- The damping time of vibrations. \([ps]\)

Returns

Value of the isotropic part of the Raman response function at the time given as parameter. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[h_a(t) = \frac{\tau_1}{\tau_1^2 + \tau_2^2} e^{\frac{-t}{\tau_2}} \sin\big(\frac{t}{\tau_1}\big)\]

References

8

Lin, Q. and Agrawal, G.P., 2006. Raman response function for silica fibers. Optics letters, 31(21), pp.3086-3088.

static calc_h_b(time, tau_b=0.096)¶

Calculate the anisotropic part (boson peak) of the Raman response function. 9

Parameters

  • time -- The time value(s). \([ps]\)

  • tau_b -- The spectral width of the Boson peak. \([ps]\)

Returns

Value of the anisotropic part of the Raman response function at the time given as parameter. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[h_b(t) = \frac{2\tau_b - t}{\tau_b^2} e^{\frac{-t}{\tau_b}}\]

References

9

Lin, Q. and Agrawal, G.P., 2006. Raman response function for silica fibers. Optics letters, 31(21), pp.3086-3088.

static calc_raman_gain(omega_bw, h_R, center_omega, n_0, f_R, n_2)¶

Calculate the Raman gain.

Parameters

  • omega_bw -- The angular frequency bandwidth. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • h_R -- The raman response function. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • center_omega -- The center angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • n_0 -- The refractive index.

  • f_R -- The fractional contribution of the delayed Raman response. \([]\)

  • n_2 -- The non-linear index. \([m^2\cdot W^{-1}]\)

Returns

The Raman gain.

Notes

\[g_R(\Delta \omega) = \frac{\omega_0}{c n_0} f_R \chi^{(3)} \Im{\hat{h}_R(\Delta \omega)}\]

where:

\[\chi^{(3)} = \frac{4\epsilon_0 c n^2}{3} n_2\]

\(\chi^{(3)}\) is in \([m^2 \cdot V^{-2}]\).

optcom.parameters.fiber.se_power module¶

class optcom.parameters.fiber.se_power.SEPower(domega)¶

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

Parameters

domega -- The angular frequency step. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

static calc_se_power(omega, domega)¶

Calculate the spontaneous emission power.

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • domega -- The angular frequency step. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

Returns

Value of the spontaneous emission power. \([W]\)

Notes

\[P_{SE} = \frac{h\omega \Delta\omega}{2\pi^{2}}\]

Bases: optcom.parameters.abstract_parameter.AbstractParameter

static calc_v_number(omega, NA, core_radius)¶

Calculate the V parameter.

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • NA -- The numerical aperture.

  • core_radius -- The radius of the core. \([\mu m]\)

Returns

Value of the V parameter.

Notes

\[V = k_0 a \text{NA} = \frac{\omega_0}{c} a \text{NA}\]
